awd_titl_txt: Molecular and proteomic analysis of neurodevelopmental signaling in C. elegans
awd_abstract_narration:
At present, we have a relatively limited understanding of how the human nervous system develops. The complexity of our brains, which are composed of billions of neurons that make trillions of cellular connections called synapses, has made this a very important, but difficult problem to understand. The simpler nervous systems of invertebrates, such as flies and nematodes, allow us to study the basic and evolutionarily conserved mechanisms responsible for nervous system development in a less complex and more manageable model system. 
	The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has emerged as an exceptionally powerful system for studying how neurons develop and form their intercellular connections (synapses). Our proposal uses biochemical, genetic and proteomic approaches to study the molecular processes that regulate neuronal and synaptic development. Specifically, we will utilize a previously characterized presynaptic protein called rpm-1 to identify additional molecules that interact with rpm-1 to facilitate neuronal and synaptic development. The successful completion of our project will lead to new insights into the molecular mechanisms that control development of the nervous system. Given that the molecules we study are evolutionarily conserved from C. elegans to human beings, the knowledge we gain will also be highly applicable to our understanding the mechanisms that drive development of the human brain. 
	Because C. elegans is a non-parasitic nematode, is small in size, and is easy to manipulate, it is an ideal organism for teaching students about nervous systems function. Our research will be directly integrated with educating the community about neuroscience through outreach efforts directed at elementary, secondary and post-secondary students.

por.por_cntn:
How is the nervous system built? This is a tremendously complex and important question that has fascinated neuroscientists for decades. Deciphering how axons develop, form synaptic connections, and terminate outgrowth is central to understanding the conserved principles that govern nervous system construction from simple invertebrates, such as the nematode C. elegans, to humans. The goal of this proposal has been to explore the molecular mechanisms that regulate axon termination and synapse formation. Our studies have focused on two types of neurons in C. elegans: The motor neurons, which form connections with muscles; and the mechanosensory neurons, which form neuron-neuron synaptic connections reminiscent of those in the central nervous system. We have focused our work on a central regulatory molecule, the Regulator of Presynaptic Morphology 1 (RPM-1), which controls both axon termination and synapse formation. At the onset of this grant, only two mechanisms of function had been described for RPM-1. By using a combination of proteomic, biochemical, genetic, and transgenic approaches we have deciphered several new mechanisms by which RPM-1 functions. Our major discoveries that were facilitated by support from this NSF grant have included the following.

1) Our work has shown that RPM-1 functions via a pathway composed of the Nesprin ANC-1 and beta-catenin to regulate axon termination and synapse formation. This is a new and unexpected mechanism that represents the first strong evidence that Nesprins regulate axon and synapse development. Our findings are described in detail in a paper by Tulgren et al entitled: The Nesprin Family Member ANC-1 Regulates Synapse Formation and Axon Termination by Functioning in a Pathway with RPM-1 and beta-Catenin (PLoS Genetics, 2014).

2) We have performed an in depth structure-function analysis of the RPM-1/FSN-1 ubiquitin ligase complex using both heterologous expression systems and C. elegans. Our results provide key structural insight into not only C. elegans RPM-1, but also orthologous proteins in mice and humans. Importantly, our findings indicate that RPM-1 uses distinct biochemical mechanisms to bind/acquire target molecules and ubiquitinate targets. Our results indicate that RPM-1, and orthologous proteins, are likely to be non-canonical ubiquitin ligases. As part of these experiments, we have also devised a positive selection system that makes in vivo biochemistry from the nervous system of C. elegans more efficient and sensitive. This should greatly aid other investigators in using biochemical approaches in C. elegans. While worms have been primarily used as a genetic model system, our hope is that this innovation will lead to more widespread us of C. elegans for biochemical studies. Our findings are described in several manuscripts.

- Sharma et al entitled: Identification of a Peptide Inhibitor of the RPM-1/FSN-1 Ubiquitin Ligase Complex (Journal of Biological Chemistry, 2014).

- Baker et al entitled: Neuronal Development in Caenorhabditis elegans Is   Regulated by Inhibition of an MLK MAP Kinase Pathway

 - Further findings on this subject will be presented shortly in an upcoming paper by Baker et al.

3) While RPM-1 was known to regulate axon termination in the mechanosensory neurons, our findings indicate that RPM-1 also regulates axon termination in the motor neurons. This demonstrates that RPM-1 regulates axon termination as a primary function in different parts of the nervous system. Our findings are presented in a paper by Opperman and colleagues entitled: RPM-1 is localized to distinct subcellular compartments and regulates axon length in GABAergic motor neurons (Neural Development 2014).

4) To communicate our findings more broadly to the general scientific audience and the public, we have published a recent review on how RPM-1 regulates axon and synapse development (Grill et al, Neural Development 2016).

5) Finally, our grant has impacted the community more broadly on two levels. First, during the course of this grant we trained three high school teachers to use C. elegans as an in-class tool for teaching students about genetics and neuroscience. Second, two undergraduate students have been trained in the scientific method, wet lab skills, and neuroscience through internships and honors theses. One of these students is a Hispanic minority in science.

Overall, our grant has resulted in important scientific progress, training numerous scientific personnel, and expanded education outreach for both high school teachers and undergraduate students.
